title: Effectiveness of Environmental Therapy in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most frequent form of dementia, causing high level of disability with elevated social costs. Alternative solutions to the standard pharmacological therapies have been studied in order to reduce the use of medications that frequently generates side effects and worsen patients' quality of life. A recent alternative treatment for AD is the Environmental Ecological Therapy (EET) that, with the use of therapeutic gardens, seems to reduce behavioral disorders (BD). However, the effectiveness of this approach is still mater of debate. Therefore, the aim of this trial will be to analyze the effects of EET, in people with severe AD.
description_detailed:
Since Homo sapiens evolved in a natural environment, an intrinsic physiologic and psychological positive reaction to nature has been developed. Accordingly, emerging literature highlights the positive effect of therapeutic gardens, as environmental ecological therapy (EET) on the reduction of behavioral disorders (BD) and the preservation of cognitive functions in patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD).

Despite these promising preliminary studies, limited data are available on the effectiveness of EET in individuals with advanced AD. Therefore, the aim of the current trial will be to evaluate the effectiveness of EET on AD symptoms in patients with advanced AD.

Participants with advanced AD will be selected from among residents of the Alzheimer's care units of the Mons. Mazzali Foundation (Mantua, Italy). Selected participants will be randomly assigned to a treatment group (TR), or to a control group (CTRL).

Participants assigned to TR group will perform a program of EET for 2 hours a day, 5 days a week for a total of 6 months. Individuals assigned to the CTRL group will be treated with a standard therapy.

groups.title: Experimental Group (TR)
groups.description:
A group of 82 patients with AD performed a program of EET for 2 hours a day, 5 days a week for a total of 6 months.

Ecological Environmental therapy: The program of EET consist of the physical interaction (visual, tactile, olfactory) between natural ecological elements such as flowers, trees, grass, and the patients with AD.

groups.title: Control Group (CTRL)
groups.description: A group of 81 patients with AD were treated with the standard therapy.

groups.title: Total
groups.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcomeMeasures.title: Evaluations of Behavioral Disorders
outcomeMeasures.description: Through the use of Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI), the investigators assessed the frequency and the severity of the behavioral disorders. The total scale range of the NPI is 0-144, and higher values represent worse outcome.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

groups.title: Experimental Group (TR)
groups.description:
A group of 82 patients with AD performed a program of EET for 2 hours a day, 5 days a week for a total of 6 months.

Ecological Environmental therapy: The program of EET consist of the physical interaction (visual, tactile, olfactory) between natural ecological elements such as flowers, trees, grass, and the patients with AD.

groups.title: Control Group (CTRL)
groups.description: A group of 81 patients with AD were treated with the standard therapy.

outcomeMeasures.title: Evaluation of Cognitive Status (Score 0-30)
outcomeMeasures.description: Through the use of Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) the investigators estimated the severity and progression of cognitive impairment. MMSE is a questionnaire that examines cognitive functions including registration, attention, calculation, recall, language, ability to follow simple commands and orientation. The scale range of the MMSE tests is 0-30, and higher values represent a better outcome.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

outcomeMeasures.title: Body Composition (Kilograms of Fat Free Mass)
outcomeMeasures.description: Body mass and skin-fold measurements were measured three times a day by the same experienced operator. The average value of the three measurements was calculated. Kilograms of fat free mass was estimated using a validated equation.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

outcomeMeasures.title: Systolic Blood Pressure (mmHg)
outcomeMeasures.description: Systolic blood pressure were measured with standard auscultatory and mercury sphygmomanometer technique.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

outcomeMeasures.title: Daily Energy Expenditure (Kcal/Day)
outcomeMeasures.description: Daily energy expenditure was measured with an Actiheart device (CamNtech, Cambridge, UK) allowing heart rate and acceleration data to be simultaneously recorded for 24 h/day for 7 consecutive days.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

groups.description:

outcomeMeasures.title: Evaluation of Activity of Daily Life
outcomeMeasures.description: Independence and level of activities of daily life (ADL) were evaluated with the Barthel index. Levels of ADL was measured by observing each resident's daily activities (eating, bathing, grooming, dressing, transfers from bed to chair, mobility on level planes, stairs, and getting on/off the toilet). The total score of the Barthel index is 0-100, and higher values represent a better outcome.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

groups.title: Experimental Group (TR)
groups.description:
A group of 82 patients with AD performed a program of EET for 2 hours a day, 5 days a week for a total of 6 months.

Ecological Environmental therapy: The program of EET consist of the physical interaction (visual, tactile, olfactory) between natural ecological elements such as flowers, trees, grass, and the patients with AD.

groups.title: Control Group (CTRL)
groups.description: A group of 81 patients with AD will be treated with the standard therapy.

outcomeMeasures.title: Salivary Cortisol (Nmol/l)
outcomeMeasures.description: Levels of cortisol was measured via saliva samples using plain Sarstedt Salivette collection devices (Nümbrecht, Germany). Samples will be collected at 6.30 AM, 11.30 AM, and 6.30 PM. Immediately after collecting the saliva samples, were centrifuged for 2 min at 1,000 rpm. Purified saliva was stored in a freezer at -20 °C, and subsequently analyzed. Cortisol levels was determined by a time-resolved immunoassay with fluorometric detection.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: PRE and POST 6 months of treatment

eventGroups.title: Experimental Group (TR)
eventGroups.description:
A group of 82 patients with AD will perform a program of EET for 2 hours a day, 5 days a week for a total of 6 months.

Ecological Environmental therapy: The program of EET consist of the physical interaction (visual, tactile, olfactory) between natural ecological elements such as flowers, trees, grass, and the patients with AD.

eventGroups.title: Control Group (CTRL)

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is Environmental Ecological Therapy (use of therapeutic gardens), a non‑pharmacological/environmental approach intended to reduce behavioral disorders and improve mood/quality of life in people with severe Alzheimer’s disease. This aims at managing neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms (e.g., agitation, depression, BPSD) rather than targeting AD molecular pathology or providing a cognitive‑enhancing drug, so it fits the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category. citeturn0search1turn0search8

Act: Key details extracted from the trial description — intervention: Environmental Ecological Therapy (therapeutic gardens); population: people with severe AD; intended effect: reduction of behavioral disorders/BD. No drug or placebo is involved. Randomized and other studies of therapeutic gardens report reductions in neuropsychiatric symptoms, agitation, medication use, and improvements in mood/quality of life, supporting classification as neuropsychiatric symptom management. citeturn0search0turn0search4
Supporting evidence (web search results): Indoor therapeutic garden RCT showing large NPI reduction and reduced antipsychotic use. citeturn0search0

Supporting evidence (web search results): Systematic reviews and narrative reviews reporting that therapeutic gardens/horticultural/environment‑based interventions improve engagement, agitation, mood, stress, and medication use in people with dementia. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Supporting evidence (web search results): Meta‑analysis and additional pilot studies reporting benefits of horticultural/therapy garden interventions for cognition, depression, ADL and quality of life, though authors note variable study quality and the need for more high‑quality trials. citeturn0search2turn0search6

Reflect: Classification checked against definitions — not a biologic or small molecule (no pharmacologic agent or mechanism targeting amyloid/tau), not primarily a cognitive‑enhancer drug, and clearly aimed at behavioral/neuropsychiatric symptom reduction. Therefore the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. No drug or placebo to report; evidence citations above provided for transparency.
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is Environmental Ecological Therapy (therapeutic/indoor gardens), a non‑pharmacological, environmental approach intended to reduce behavioral and neuropsychiatric symptoms (BPSD) and improve mood/quality of life in people with severe AD — it does not act on a molecular AD target (amyloid, tau, inflammation pathway, neurotransmitter receptor, etc.). citeturn0search0turn0search2

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: Environmental Ecological Therapy / therapeutic gardens; population: people with severe Alzheimer's disease; intended effect: reduction of behavioral disorders/agitation, improved mood and quality of life; no drug, gene, or biochemical pathway is targeted. RCT(s) and systematic reviews/meta-analyses report reductions in neuropsychiatric symptoms and improvements in engagement/quality of life with horticultural/therapeutic garden interventions. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search1

- An indoor therapeutic garden randomized controlled trial (N=163) showed large Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) score improvement, reduced antipsychotic (quetiapine) use and reduced cortisol. citeturn0search0

- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses report that horticultural/therapeutic garden interventions reduce agitation and improve engagement, mood, ADLs and quality of life in people with dementia. citeturn0search2turn0search4turn0search1

Reflect: CADRO is organized around biological and pharmacologic targets (amyloid, tau, inflammation, neurotransmitters, etc.). This trial evaluates an environmental/behavioral therapy with no specified molecular target or pharmacologic agent, so it does not map to a biological CADRO category. Per the instructions, non‑pharmacologic/non‑biologic interventions that do not fit CADRO therapeutic target categories should be classified as 'T) Other.' Confirmed.
